dc:title: The effect of host-plant species on adult weight and the reproductive potential of aphids.
dc:creator: Llewellyn M.
dc:description: Adult aphids were collected from host-plants in the field and individuals of the alate and apterous morphs were weighed and their embryo content assessed. Seventeen of the aphid species were feeding on >1 host-plant. For alate morphs, 7 of 8 comparisons indicate that adult weight is significantly affected by host-plant differences; 63% of comparisons also indicate that embryo content is affected. For apterous morphs, 17 of 22 comparisons show that host-plant influences adult weight; in 75% of the cases embryo content is likewise influenced. Adult weight and embryo content of Aphis fabae and A. pomi decline during the summer, then increase. The influence of host-plants on these variables is discussed. Adult weight and embryo content of the host-alternating A. fabae and Macrosiphum rosae are compared on their primary woody host-plant and the secondary herbaceous plant. Neither host provides a clear reproductive advantage over the other. -from Authors

dc:title: Transmission dynamics of Profilicollis botulus ( Acanthocephala) from crabs ( Carcinus maenas) to eider ducks ( Somateria mollissima) on the Ythan estuary, NE Scotland.
dc:creator: Thompson A.
dc:description: Eider faeces were collected from roost sites on the Ythan estuary, Aberdeenshire. Portions of crab chelipeds were used to obtain the mean numbers and sizes of C. maenas eaten by eiders. The mean sizes of crab eaten varied only slightly, but there was a bimodal pattern in the number of crabs eaten per eider per day throughout the year. The mean number of P. botulus cystacanths eaten per eider per day throughout the year was calculated. -from Author

dc:title: The energy budget and population structure of Nucula turgida in Dublin Bay.
dc:creator: Davis J.
dc:description: The Nucula turgida population in Dublin Bay had a maximum of 6 year-classes with a single spawning in September. The energy budget for the population was: consumption, C= 2219 kJ m-2 yr-1; production P = 20 kJ m-2yr-1 respiration, R = 66 kJ m-2yr-1; gonad output, G = 17 kJ m-2yr-1; egestion, F = 1515 kJ m-2yr-1 with the imbalance probably due to an overestimate of consumption. The amount of sediment processed (C, F) by N. turgida was extremely large compared to the remainder of the energy budget (P, R, G). This bivalve's major contribution to the assimilation of organic matter into the system may be indirectly through sediment modification. The P:B ratio was 1:0.60, with a respiration assimilation of 64% and a net growth efficiency of 36%. Nucula turgida, compared to other bivalves, apportioned more to gonad than somatic growth due to the lipid content of the eggs. -from Authors

dc:title: Feeding ecology of Pipistrellus pipistrellus ( Chiroptera: Vespertilionidae) during pregnancy and lactation. I. Foraging behaviour.
dc:creator: Racey P.
dc:description: In a lowland agricultural area where the habitat suitable for foraging was extensive, mean distance between the roost and bats during pregnancy was 1.8 km and maximum recorded distance was 5.1 km. These distances were reduced to 1.3 km and 3.7 km respectively during lactation. In an upland area, bats foraged in all habitats where insects were abundant both before and after parturition. Average distance between the roost and foraging sites was 1.0 km and maximum distance 2.5 km during both pregnancy and lactation. Pipistrelles moved between foraging sites on a regular route, and were sighted at the same time and place on successive nights. Pipistrelles left the roost and travelled between foraging sites in groups of 2-6 individuals: 'following' behaviour involving 2 bats was frequently observed. Bats foraged on beats which were seldom defended. Intra-specific aggression was evident only at low insect densities: at high insect densities large numbers of bats foraged in small areas without showing any overt aggression. The rate at which P. pipistrellus attacked insects was proportional to insect density until a maximum rate of 10 'feeding buzzes' per minute was reached. Bats did not remain in an area or attempt to forage if the insect density was <300-1000-3 m. Juvenile P. pipistrellus moved progressively further from the roost over a 3 wk period after they first began to fly. The recorded rate of attempted feeding also increased progressively during this period.-from Authors

dc:title: Feeding ecology of Pipistrellus pipistrellus ( Chiroptera: Vespertilionidae) during pregnancy and lactation. II. Diet.
dc:creator: Swift S.M.
dc:description: The representation of different groups of insects in the diet of pipistrell bats, determined by faecal analysis, was compared with their representation in suction trap samples on the same 18 nights during pregnancy and lactation. Pipistrelles fed mainly on Nematocera and Trichoptera. Composition of their diet reflected the availability of these insects over a wide range of abundance. There was no evidence that pipistrelles selected their diet on the basis of insect size. Ephemeroptera nd Neuroptera were significantly over represented in the diet and Nematocera, Coleoptera and Lepidoptera were significantly under represented. No differences in diet were recorded between sexes or between pregnant and lactating females.-Authors

dc:title: Metabolic rates and pit-construction costs of two antlion species.
dc:creator: Lucas J.
dc:description: Second and third instar Myrmeleon carolinus have a lower resting metabolism than similar instars of M. crudelis, while metabolism was similar between first instars. Differences between species increased with increasing temperatures. These differences correlate with environmental temperatures of the habitats of each species: M. carolinus is found in hot, open areas, M. crudelis in cooler, shaded areas. Metabolic expenditure during pit constructions was c10 X resting metabolic rates for 2nd and 3rd instar larvae, although this ratio decreased with increasing temperature. Differences in construction metabolism between species were qualitatively similar to resting metabolism: higher for M. crudelis. Total metabolic cost of pit construction (the rate of oxygen uptake multiplied by the time required to construct a pit) increased with increasing pit diameter. Total cost also decreased with increasing temperature for M. crudelis and for 3rd instar M. carolinus. The energetic consequences of dusk pit-construction are discussed in the light of these relationships between pit cost and temperature.-from Author

dc:title: Sycamore aphid numbers and population density. II. Some processes.
dc:creator: Chambers R.
dc:description: Laboratory populations of Drepanosiphum platanoidis tend to reach an asymptotic density in the autumn, irrespective of the initial number of aphids colonizing the trees. This population behaviour is not observed in the field populations, where immigration and density-disturbing weather conditions may be important. Analysis of laboratory data identified 2 density-dependent processes: flight by adult 1st generation aphids and reduced fecundity of 2nd-generation adults as a result of crowding experience. Growth and development rates of individual aphids were influenced by the nutritional value of their host plant and by crowding density. Other experiments indicated that the effect of crowding was mediated through the host plant, rather than solely through direct behavioural interactions. This effect was shown to act during development and the pre-reproductive period, as well as on the reproductive rate of adults. The role of these intraspecific processes in the regulation of sycamore aphid numbers is discussed.-from Authors

dc:title: A simulation model for an acarine predator-prey system ( Phytoseiulus persimilis- Tetranychus urticae).
dc:creator: Bernstein C.
dc:description: The model simulates the population dynamics of 2 mites, prey and predator, on a single plant. In addition to the reproduction and age structure of both populations and the attack on the prey by the predators, the model explicitly includes the damage the prey (a phytophage) causes to the plant and the emigration of prey and predators. Sensitivity analysis shows that the most critical parameters are those affecting the reproduction of prey and predators.-from Author

dc:title: Analysis of Profilicollis botulus ( Acanthocephala: Echinorhynchidae) burdens in the shore crab, Carcinus maenas.
dc:creator: Thompson A.
dc:description: Profilicollis botulus is an acanthocephalan parasite of eider Somateria mollissima (definitive host) and shore crab Carcinus maenas (intermediate host). Carcinus maenas with carapace widths of 15-64 mm were sampled from the Ythan estuary, Aberdeenshire. Mean size and sex ratio of the crabs varied seasonally and between sampling locality. A positive relationship existed between crab size and the mean number of P. botulus per crab. -from Author

dc:title: Insect natural enemies as regulating factors.
dc:creator: Hassell M.
dc:description: The view that natural enemies are important in the regulation of temperate Lepidoptera populations has been challenged by Dempster (1983), based on examining 24 sets of life tables of Lepidoptera populations with more-or-less discrete generations, all but 3 of which failed to reveal natural enemies as density-dependent factors when analysed using the conventional technique of plotting some measure of proportionate mortality against population density per generation. This conclusion is challenged on the basis of how difficult it is to detect natural enemies as density-dependent factors, especially when they act together with other stochastic processes. The point is illustrated by analysing model populations in which the parasitoids are the only regulating factor. The problem lies in attempting to detect density dependence that arises within a generation (eg by non-random parasitism between patches of different host density) from estimates of mean population size per generation. The only real solution is to seek much more detailed information from within each generation, and thus to design life table sampling programmes that are stratified in the 2 dimensions of space and time.-Author

dc:title: Details of geographic replacement of the red squirrel ( Sciurus vulgaris) by the grey squirrel ( Sciurus carolinensis) in eastern England.
dc:creator: Reynolds J.C.
dc:description: Details of the replacement are revealed by a series of 22 annual distribution maps (1960-81). Colonization of the region by invading grey squirrels was patchy. Pioneer populations were often detached from the main distribution of the species. Similarly, the red squirrel in decline was reduced to scattered 'island' populations. Interaction between the species could at the most provide a partial explanation of red squirrel decline: in many cases, red squirrels became locally extinct before establishment of grey squirrels in the same area. In other cases, coexistence occurred for up to 16 yr, or continued in 1982. Grey squirrel presence per se did not enhance the probability of red squirrel extinction. However, the more plausible possibilities of density-dependent interaction could not be tested in this extensive approach. The loss of local red squirrel populations showed no temporal or spatial grouping. A viral disease caused high death-rates locally in red squirrel populations, sometimes resulting in local extinction, but was not recorded in grey squirrels. Outbreaks frequently arose outside the current geographical range of the grey squirrel, weakening the hypothesis of the latter species as an immune vector. Outbreaks showed no temporal grouping.-Author

dc:title: The effect of enlarged brood size on the future reproductive potential of the rook.
dc:creator: Roskaft E.
dc:description: Corvus frugilegus successfully reared experimentally enlarged broods. There was no statistically significant effect of brood enlargement on the survival rate of the adults. Compared to the unmanipulated control pairs, the pairs given enlarged broods in the preceding year laid a week later and reared fewer young than in the preceding year.-Author

dc:title: Lifetime reproductive output of female sparrowhawks.
dc:creator: Newton I.
dc:description: Number of fledglings reared in a lifetime was determined for a sample of 142 female Accipiter nisus. They raised between 0-23 young during their lives, the number varying primarily with longevity, as long-lived females in general raised more young than short-lived ones. Lifetime production was also greater in longer-winged females (assumed to reflect larger body-size) and in females that had been raised in the study areas than in those which had moved in from elsewhere. It did not vary with type of natal or breeding habitat. Number of fledglings reared by individuals correlated with the number subsequently recruited to the breeding population. Overall, c23.5% of fledgling females from one generation contributed fledglings to the next. About 72% of fledglings died before they could breed, and another 4.5% attempted to breed, but did not raise young. Some 18% of surviving females had bred by the end of their 1st yr, 49% by the end of their 2nd, 83% by the end of their 3rd, and the remainder by the end of their 4th. Occasional individuals which had bred in a previous year missed = or >1 yr in later life. Delayed breeding by the majority of females was attributed to shortage of mates or food, rather than to individuals holding back to enhance production in later life.-from Author

dc:title: The effects of density-dependent resource limitations on the demography of wild reindeer.
dc:creator: Skogland T.
dc:description: Density-dependent effects in Norwegian Rangifer tarandus were manifested through winter food limitation. With increasing densities, density-independent factors such as severe weather had additional effects on recruitment, with consequences for population stability. The density effect took the form of decreased juvenile survival; adult survival in the most abundant and reproductive age classes was not affected. At high density, subadult fecundity fell below the threshold body size for maturity. Fecundity of adults was not affected by density. Density-dependent food limitation was most apparent at high population density.-from Author

dc:title: Population cycles over a 16-year period in an upland race of Strophingia ericae ( Homoptera: Psylloidea) on Calluna vulgaris.
dc:creator: Whittaker J.
dc:description: Strophingia ericae feeding on phloem sap of Calluna vulgaris has a 2-yr life cycle in which the cohorts overlap at high altitudes. The dynamics of this species were studied on the Moor House National Nature Reserve. Overlapping cohorts which appear to constitute separate gene pools coexist on the same Calluna shoots. Small individuals of each new cohort are likely to be exploiting the same resources as large individuals of the previous cohort. Each cohort set (odd or even years) showed 3 regularly spaced peaks of abundance during the 16 yr. When recruitment to a new cohort ended, mortality became density independent up to the onset of winter. Mortality was very low during winter and there was little change in age structure from November-March. Mortality from the 1st spring to the 2nd winter was density dependent. Again during the 2nd winter there was little mortality or change in age structure. Mortality from the 2nd spring to the end of the life cycle was density dependent. Log increase in biomass of a new cohort during its first full year was negatively correlated with the log total biomass of psyllids in both cohorts, but not significantly correlated with the log biomass of the new cohort. This interaction appeared to be the cause of oscillation in biomass from one year to the next.-from Author

dc:title: Parasitoid foraging: should parasitism be density dependent?
dc:creator: Lessells C.
dc:description: Investigates how the percentage of hosts parasitized should vary with initial density in different patches if parasitoids maximize their oviposition rate, and compares the theoretical expectations with patterns of parasitism reported in the literature. If rejection time of parasitized hosts is the only factor limiting parasitoid efficiency between patches, parasitism should always be density dependent. If there is interference between parasitoids, and the relationship between log searching efficiency and log parasitoid density is linear, parasitism should either be density dependent or inversely density dependent at all host densities. However, although the latter is theoretically possible it is practically unlikely. If the interference relationship is curvilinear (and m asymptotes at 1), parasitism should be density dependent at low host densities and density independent at high host densities. Egg or time limitation, or imperfect information on patch quality are constraints on parasitoid foraging which may produce inversely density dependent parasitism or 'domed' density relationships.-Author

dc:title: Responses to Seychelles tropical forest seasons by a litter- foraging mammalian insectivore, Tenrec ecaudatus, native to Madagascar.
dc:creator: Nicoll M.
dc:description: Ambient temperatures vary little in the Seychelles, but tenrecs show hypothermia for c6 months each year when food availability is lowest. Following cessation of the annual period of reproduction, which coincides with moult, tenrecs fatten rapidly before becoming torpid, males earlier than females. Males may commence seasonal hypothermia earlier than females and always emerge c1 month earlier than females, beginning in June-July. Testicular recrudescence to the completion of spermatogenesis and growth of ovarian follicles begins before emergence, ensuring physiological readiness to mate soon after arousal. Females conceive soon after emergence although spermatogenesis continues until November-December. Most births occur in December, coinciding with peak food supply, but have been recorded throughout the year. Foetal survival and litter size decrease after December. The relative size of the placenta accounts for 41% of the variation in foetus survival.-from Author

dc:title: Selective basis for emigration of the prairie vole, Microtus ochrogaster: open field experiment.
dc:creator: Johnson M.
dc:description: Tested the hypothesis that for prairie voles, emigrating from and staying in a site are components of a mixed evolutionary stable strategy with emigrants and residents having equal fitness in terms of survival and reproductive activity. Emigrants were predicted to have greater fitness than residents during colonization of a site since their fitness is reduced between leaving their home site and settling elsewhere. Three populations were live-trapped from 1979-82: a control (grid A), and experimental (grid G and I). Voles were allowed to enter and colonize the experimental sites for either 8 or 16 wk intervals, run concurrently. Survival rates of emigrants were higher than those of residents in all cases except for those of adult females on Grid G. Reproductive activity of males on both experimental grids, and subadult and juvenile females on grid I was higher than the corresponding group of residents. Results were consistent with 4 predictions. Females on grid G consistently had lowest fitness. Grid G seemed to represent suboptimal habitat for females.-from Authors

dc:title: A simulation study of primary-, clepto- and hyperparasitism in Epinotia tedella ( Lepidoptera, Tortricidae).
dc:creator: Munster-Swendsen M.
dc:description: A model of combined parasitism in the spruce needleminer is proposed. It covers the effect of 2 primary parasitoids, Pimplopterus dubius and Apanteles tedellae, a cleptoparasitoid, Campoplex cursitans, and a hyperparasitoid, Mesochorus silvarum. Introduction of a second primary parasitoid is shown to decrease the equilibrium host density considerably, whereas the presence of hyperparasitoids improves stability. The host-parasitoid system proves stable when the power of increase of the host is <17, or <13 in the absence of clepto- and hyperparasitoids. Parasitism is evaluated as an element in the complex of natural mortality factors acting on Epinotia tedella. The additional mortalities of the model are egg mortality due to Trichogramma evanescens, larval mycosis caused by the fungus Paecilomyces farinosus, and larval and pupal predation due to the elaterid Athous subfuscus. Parasitism proves to be the superior agent in the reduction and stabilization of the host density. Removal of parasitism causes a 10-fold increase in the equilibrium host density.-from Author

dc:title: Estimation of the survival rate of Anopheles arabiensis in an urban area ( Pikine- Senegal).
dc:creator: Vercruysse J.
dc:description: Best estimate the daily survival rate of the biting population of Anopheles arabiensis was 0.82 + or - 0.02 SE.-from Author

dc:title: Litter arthropod population in a tropical deciduous forest: relationships between years and arthropod groups.
dc:creator: Levings S.
dc:description: Examines variability in the pattern of population fluctuations among years and litter arthropod groups in moist tropical forest on Barro Colorado Island, Republic of Panama. Major arthropod groups showed 3 main patterns of seasonal abundance: dry season increase (2 groups), early wet season maxima (9 groups) and no fluctuations or fluctuations independent of seasonal patterns (6 groups). Among years, the rank order of abundance in seasonal comparisons was highly correlated. All groups tended to have high or low populations in the same year.-from Authors

dc:title: Phenology and larval-adult size relations in the ant-lion Macroleon quinquemaculatus.
dc:creator: Griffiths D.
dc:description: Larvae of Macroleon quinquemaculatus pupate in the rainy seasons which occur in the Dar es Salaam area, Tanzania, in March-May and September-December. Size of pupating larvae varies greatly. Hunger can induce pupation. The time when a larva pupates within a rainy season is inversely related to larval weight. Larvae usually pupate within 2 days of leaving their pits but some larger larvae delay pupation for up to 4 months. All pupating larvae emerge as adults, but there are 3 distinct size classes of larvae: those <140 mg become adults that are a decreasing percentage of larval weight, whereas larger larvae become adults that are a constant or an increasing percentage of larval weight. Adult females show 2 length-weight relationships, small adult females (from larvae <140 mg) being relatively shorter than large adults. Mean egg size and fat content of adults increases with adult weight. Larvae pupating when small thus apparently become adults of reduced fitness. -from Author

dc:title: Nest hole shift in Tengmalm's owl Aegolius funereus as defence against nest predation involving long-term memory in the predator.
dc:creator: Sonerud G.
dc:description: In SE Norway, 48% of Tengmalm owl clutches were preyed upon; of these at least 70% and possibly all, were taken by pine martens Martes martes. Frequency of predation increased with nest box age, but was independent of nest density, which fluctuated in parallel with numbers of small rodents, the staple prey of Tengmalm's owls and pine martens. Tengmalm's owl clutches had a higher probability of being preyed upon in nest boxes where the previous clutch had been taken than in boxes where there had been a successful nesting the previous year. Pine martens thus did not encounter nest boxes randomly, but revisited those that they had found previously. Tengmalm's owls preferred to nest in new boxes, and a majority of the females shifted nest hole between successful nestings. Clutches initiated in March were in newer boxes than were later clutches, and were thus less exposed to predation. This predation situation will select for owl individuals which move to another hole after having a clutch preyed upon. If new holes become available each year it will also select for individuals which shift nest hole between successful nesting and prefer nesting in new holes.-from Author

dc:title: Assessing survival rates of Anopheles farauti ( Diptera: Culicidae) from Papua New Guinea.
dc:creator: Charlwood J.
dc:description: Estimates of survival rates per oviposition cycle, estimated by 4 different methods, ranged between 0.32-0.64 in the wet season and 0.49-0.73 in the dry season. The actual survival rate per cycle was probably 0.42-0.49 in both seasons. The oviposition cycle interval was estimated as 2.47 days in the wet and 2.20 days in the dry season. The interval between emergence and first blood-meal was 4 days. Severe rainstorms affected recruitment in the wet season but not in the dry season.-from Authors

dc:title: The effect of larval density on adult longevity of a mosquito, Aedes sierrensis: epidemiological consequences.
dc:creator: Hawley W.
dc:description: A 3-yr field study of larval populations of Aedes sierrensis, a common North American tree-hole mosquito, produced no evidence for density-dependent larval mortality, but revealed that pupal weight of females was inversely correlated with larval density. In general, larger adults lived longer than smaller ones. The interval between blood meals in nature was c8 days. The total expectation of infective life (for transmission of a nematode, Dirofilaria immitis) for females was estimated within the range of larval densities observed in nature. As these estimates may be maximal at intermediate population densities, reduction of larval density may result in an increase in the capacity of the adult population to transmit disease.-Author

dc:title: The influence of larval dispersal in the cinnabar moth ( Tyria jacobaeae) on predation by the red wood ant ( Formica polyctena): an analysis based on the proportional hazards model.
dc:creator: Haccou P.
dc:description: Behaviour of larvae had the largest effect on the risk of attack. The attack rate on larvae in plants or grass leaves was <0.34 times the attack rate on larvae on the ground. Risk of attack also increased with the mean number of larvae per plant and larvae in clumped distributions (on the spatial scale of a plant population) apparently had a lower risk of attack than larvae in regular distributions.-from Authors

dc:title: Central place foraging in the European bee-eater, Merops apiaster.
dc:creator: Krebs J.R.
dc:description: Tested whether variation in the size of prey fed by parent bee-eaters to nestlings could be explained by a model of central-place foraging. The model predicted that selectivity for large prey should increase with distance travelled by the parents from the nest to the feeding site. Most of the prey brought to the nest were odonates and hymenopterans. As predicted by the model, there was a decrease in the proportion of items brought to the nest that were small with increasing travel time. The model predicted a threshold for dropping small items from the nestling diet. Statistical estimation of a threshold from the observed data by probit analysis showed that the predicted threshold was within 2 standard errors of the observed. Estimates of relative prey abundance and observations of parents collecting food for themselves showed that differential availability of small prey at different distances from the nest could not account for the size-distance relationship.-from Authors

dc:title: Population equilibrium with respect to available food resource and its behavioural basis in an herbivorous lady beetle, Henosepilachna niponica.
dc:creator: Ohgushi T.
dc:description: Food resource abundance measured as the number of thistle shoots changed from year to year rather independently in the 2 sites, but egg populations tracked the year-to-year changes in available food supply throughout the study period in each habitat. Average egg density relative to food resource abundance over 5 yr was almost identical between the 2 local populations. After detectable external perturbations, mainly large-scale floods and arthropod predation, the egg populations quickly returned to the previous level of density. The local populations of the lady beetle actually persist in a dynamic equilibrium, maintaining a constant density with respect to the amount of available food resource. The egg populations approached, asymptotically, a plateau of a certain level of density per unit resource throughout the reproductive season in every year. The possible regulatory process responsible for the population saturation involves the reduction in oviposition rate responding to cumulative egg load in the later season and, to a lesser extent, density-dependent losses of reproductive females probably due to dispersal in the early season. Resorption of developing eggs in the ovary and frequent inter-plant movements of females for oviposition are causal behavioural bases producing a dynamic equilibrium state in the lady beetle and thistle system in every year. -from Authors

dc:title: Aggregation by parasitoids in the successful control of the California red scale: a test of theory.
dc:creator: Reeve J.
dc:description: Examined the interaction between red scale, a pest of citrus, and its parasitoid Aphytis melinus, in a lemon grove in Southern California. The scale is under successful control by the parasitoid and the interaction appears to be stable. The existing theory that parasitoid aggregation in space is a key feature of such successful and stable control was tested. The critical variable is the distribution of the parasitism rate. Theory shows that a strong relationship between parasitism rate and local pest density may stabilize a parasitoid-host system, and also that strong clumping of parasitism among pests, independent of their local density, is stabilizing. No evidence was found at any spatial level for aggregation of parasitism in response to local host density, or for sufficiently strong aggregation independent of local host density. Parasitism tended to be homogeneous in space. Parasitoids themselves also did not appear to aggregate to local host density.-from Authors

dc:title: Does interspecific competition or predation shape the African ungulate community?
dc:creator: Sinclair A.
dc:description: The ungulate community in the Serengeti-Mara region of Tanzania and Kenya was examined between 1980-83. The wildebeest Connochaetes taurinus migration provided a natural experiment to alter the intensity of interspecific competition among 8 other species of grazing ungulated. There was a high similarity in vegetation choice between species, and a large overlap with the competing wildebeest. Most species were found closer to wildebeest than an expected random distribution would suggest. Comparing results with predictions, they suggest that Thomson's Gazella thomsoni and Grant's gazelles G. granti are strongly influenced by predation. Zebra Equus burchelli, topi Damaliscus korrigum, impala Aepyceros melampus, waterbuck Kobus defassa and warthog Phacochaerus aethiopicus are influenced by both predation and interspecific competition; these species may be showing a mixed evolutionarily stable strategy to cope with 2 opposing pressures. Zebra, in particular, use wildebeest to obtain protection from predators. In general predation appears to play as much a role as interspecific competition in structuring this community.-from Author

dc:title: Variation in aphid weight and reproductive potential in relation to plant growth form.
dc:creator: Brown V.
dc:description: Classified the plants used as hosts by aphids into 9 categories, based on phenology and growth form. The relative abundance of each category changes with the successional age of the habitat. The adult body weight and reproductive potential of 90 aphid species on 120 host-plants are analysed. Both alate and apterous morphs are considered. Total embryo number and number of mature embryos are used as indices of potential fecundity and short-term reproductive effort. Aphids occurring on woody plants (evergreens and deciduous trees and shrubs) are generally heavier than those on annuals, biennials and perennials. Aphids on herbaceous plants are potentially more fecund than those on woody plants. Within these categories, alate aphids on annuals have a higher reproductive potential than those on biennials and perennials while shrub-associated aphids are potentially more fecund than aphids on trees. Species on grasses and ferns have a low reproductive potential. Seasonal trends in aphid weight and reproductive potential are discussed in terms of established patterns in host-plant phenology and nutrient levels. Results lend support to classical life-cycle theory and to the successional models of Margalef and Odum. -from Authors

dc:title: Comparison of the growth rate of brown trout ( Salmo trutta) in a New Zealand stream with experimental fish in Britain.
dc:creator: Allen K.
dc:description: Comparison of the growth rate of brown trout fed to satiation under experimental conditions in Britain with that of fish at the same size and temperature under natural conditions in a fast-growing population in the Horokiwi Stream in New Zealand showed that, although there was good general agreement, there were 2 important differences. At temperatures <13oC, trout in some parts of the Horokiwi grew more rapidly than experimental fish of the same size at the same temperature. Between 13-19.5oC, growth in the Horokiwi was again more rapid than that of experimental fish, but appeared to decline with rising temperature. The temperature at which Horokiwi fish ceased to grow was likely to be >19.5oC, the limit for experimental fish. There may have been genetic selection for more rapid growth and a higher temperature limit in the Horokiwi trout; the population is derived from a very small initial liberation in 1885 and the temperature range is slightly above that in British streams. An alternative explanation is that experimental conditions did not allow the fish to achieve the maximum growth rate of which they were intrinsically capable. -from Author

dc:title: Effect of physiological condition of the host plant on the ovipositional choice of the cabbage white butterfly, Pieris rapae.
dc:creator: Myers J.
dc:description: Pieris rapae could recognize the physiological state of plants treated with fertilizer and unfertilized plants and preferentially laid eggs on plants which were better for larval development. The plants preferred by ovipositing butterflies had higher N and P content, higher transpiration rate and greener colour. The improved physiological condition of fertilized plants was detected by some butterflies only 1 day after fertilization; c5 days after fertilization, plants became greener, were approached by butterflies more frequently and received more eggs. Caterpillars grew faster and attained a heavier weight when grown on the preferred fertilized plants. Oviposition choice of adult butterflies thus translates into a fitness advantage for their offspring. The linear flight paths of cabbage white butterflies tend to cause egg spreading, but this behaviour is modified by the attractiveness of plants in good physiological condition. Butterflies may remain to lay several eggs on these plants.-from Author

dc:title: Availability of buried littleneck clams ( Venerupis japonica) to northwestern crows ( Corvus caurinus).
dc:creator: Richardson H.
dc:description: Crows' searching frequency was the same in quadrats with clams and quadrats devoid of clams and all possible surface indications of their presence. Crows were more successful per search in areas of high clam density than in areas of low density. A model was developed to estimate the relative availability of different sized clams to crows searching apparently at random. The model incorporates both the size and depth-frequency distribution of the clams and the shape and depth-frequency distribution of searches made by the crows. Crows both probed and dug for clams. The depth-frequency distribution of probes decreased with depth while that of digs was normally distributed. Clam burying depth increased with clam size. The relative availability of clams to probing was an increasing function of clam size, despite the size-depth relationship, because large clams were easier to detect than small ones at any particular depth. As big holes were widest at the surface, the smaller clams were more available to digging crows than the deeper, large clams. From the ratio of probes to digs, it was calculated that relative availability increased only slightly with clam size. The lower availability of small clams was not sufficient to account for the total absence of clams <24 mm in length from the crow's diet. This diet was therefore presumed to result from selective feeding.-from Author

dc:title: Decisions for a lifetime: establishment of spatial defence and movement patterns by juvenile grey plovers ( Pluvialis squatarola).
dc:creator: Townshend D.
dc:description: Reports on how long-term behaviour patterns of grey plovers in the non-breeding season are established in the first year of life. The behaviour of colour-marked individuals was observed at Teesmouth, NE England. Wing lengths were measured as an estimate of body size. Each individual was consistent from its first year onwards in being territorial or feeding non-territorially, and in the timing of seasonal movements to and from the estuary. The lifetime territorial behaviour and timing of seasonal movements of individuals were established during competition especially with adults. Longer-winged juveniles were more likely to acquire territories and more likely to stay at Teesmouth all winter.-from Author

dc:title: Sycamore aphid numbers and population density. I. Some patterns.
dc:creator: Wellings P.W.
dc:description: Changes in spring and autumn Drepanosiphum platanoidis numbers from year to year indicated that all 8 study populations were subject to density-dependent regulation and that the populations displayed a range of dynamic behaviour. Populations in any one year were often in synchrony, reflecting the important role of weather in driving aphid numbers. During the summer, 2nd generation adults aestivate. Duration of this aestivation was density-dependent, but undercompensatory. The synchrony of the sexual morphs in autumn was dependent on recruitment during July and thus linked with the duration of aestivation. Analysis of field data revealed some associations between aphid and host plant. Time of leaf fall was correlated with autumn aphid densities, and time of bud break and egg hatch related to the aphid densities in the previous autumn. -from Authors

dc:title: A quantitative study of the life history of a fairy shrimp ( Branchiopoda: Anostraca) in relation to the temporary nature of its habitat, a Kenyan rainpool.
dc:creator: Hildrew A.
dc:description: Two cohorts of Streptocephalus vitreus lived for 19 (short-rains cohort) and 32 days (long-rains cohort) in a temporary rainpool during 2 wet seasons. On both occasions the pool dried up when many animals were still alive and producing eggs. The instantaneous growth rate was constant between the age of 3-17 days (27.0% dry weight day-1) in the short-rains cohort, but declined with age in the long-rains cohort, being constant between day 3-5 (53.8% day-1), 9-19 (19.9% day-1 and 19-32 (1.2% day-1). Egg production began at the age of 17 days and at a mean dry weight of 300 mu g in the short-rains cohort and at the age of 14 days and weight 440 mu g in the long-rains cohort. A higher proportion of females produced eggs in the long- rather than in the short-rains cohort and average clutch size differed (42.1+ or -5.1 and 11.0+ or -1.4 respectively). There was a constant mortality rate in the long-rains cohort. Sex ratios were equal at first but favoured females after maturity. In the long-rains cohort, average daily production was 5.70 mg dry weight m-2day-1; the P/B ratio between age 3-32 days was 3.36. More eggs hatched from soil cores taken near the edge of the pool than from those near the middle. Hatching times were very variable even between eggs in the same clutch. There is extreme spreading of risk among progeny and very rapid growth to maturity. When circumstances allow, repeated copulations (probably with different males) produce further clutches of eggs.-from Author

dc:title: Density-related parasitoid sex-ratio: influence on host- parasitoid dynamics.
dc:creator: Comins H.N.
dc:description: Several mechanisms suggest that sex-ratio in arrhenotokous parasitoids may be density-related. Four models incorporating density-related parasitoid sex-ratio are presented. The cases are considered where sex-ratio is a function of 1) male parasitoid population density, 2) female parasitoid population density, 3) host population density, and 4) the ratio of females to hosts. The near-equilibrium dynamic properties of simple difference equation models, which incorporate density-related sex-ratios, are displayed. Each model is framed to incorporate the same parameter, zeta , defined as the fractional change in the proportion of female progeny per fractional change in the controlling population density or density ratio. Two constraints operate on the natural parameter combinations in these models: 1) there are strong theoretical reasons for believing that the sex-ratio is 0.5 in the absence of local mate competition, and 2) a simple global model suggests that zeta may be limited to between -0.5 and +0.5. Models incorporating sex-ratio are locally stable over a broad range of host depression below carrying capacity. Some of the models generate large host depressions, a characteristic feature of successful biological control programmes using natural enemies. -from Authors

dc:title: Coexistence of Australian rainforest Diptera breeding in fallen fruit.
dc:creator: Atkinson W.D.
dc:description: Some 28 species of Diptera, including 5 species of Drosophila were reared from fallen fruit collected in subtropical rainforest sites in E Australia. Atkinson & Shorrocks (1981) (see 82L/1479) showed that in discrete and ephemeral breeding sites, coexistence was facilitated if the competitors were aggregated. There was little niche differentiation among the flies, many of the species sharing the same kind of fruit. Though there was less overlap over individual fruit items, the dipteran species were not negatively associated as they would be if the low overlap was caused by systematic niche separation. Low overlap over fruit items would be expected if the fly populations were kept at a low level by density-independent mortality; this might also explain the persistence of a diverse community. There was, however, widespread intraspecific competition, which would not be expected if density-independent mortality was important. If this guild of flies was maintained by aggregation over discrete and ephemeral breeding sites one would expect low overlap of the species over fruit items, random associations between the species and evidence of intraspecific competition. These were all observed. Adult flies emerging from the fruits also showed sufficient aggregation to account for their coexistence, as did eggs laid in the wild on artificial breeding sites.-from Author

dc:title: Differential mortality of male and female offspring in experimentally manipulated broods of the rook.
dc:creator: Roskaft E.
dc:description: Corvus frugilegus fledglings found abandoned on the ground in 2 rookeries at Trondheim, Norway, comprised 22 males and 7 females, indicating a differential mortality among the young, according to sex. The mean body weight of abandoned young was lower than that of young of a control sample, and their tarsi were also shorter, indicating that they had starved throughout much of the nestling period. The existence of a differential mortality between male and female young was verified in an experiment in which broods were manipulated to contain 4 males or 4 females. The feeding rate of the young by the parents was independent of the sex composition of the brood, ie the parents did not alter their reproductive effort according to the composition of their brood. The rook shows sexual dimorphism in size, the adult males being about 15% heavier than the adult females. The rearing of a male offspring to independence may therefore involve a greater parental cost than the rearing of a female offspring. For the rook this difference in cost seems to be offset in the population as a whole by an increase in the mortality rate of the male offspring.-from Authors

dc:title: Effect of habitat on the life history strategies of some British grasshoppers.
dc:creator: Monk K.
dc:description: Chorthippus parallelus and C. brunneus were studied in dry grassland, wet meadow, and heathland (listed in order of decreasing favourableness). For both species, egg eclosion began in the order: dry grassland, wet meadow, heathland, thus potentially shortening the breeding season on the later sites. A decrease in the nymphal development periods on the later sites lowers the age at 1st reproduction, counteracting this. The pre-oviposition period of the adult females remains unchanged between populations. The reproductive effort of C. brunneus is greatly increased both within clutches and over the breeding season in the later populations. Larger clutches of larger eggs are produced. Total egg production per female therefore increases in the later populations. C. parallelus displays similar increased reproductive effort over the whole breeding season, but produces larger eggs in more, smaller clutches. Total egg production per female does not vary between populations. The suitability for egg development appears to decrease from dry grassland to wet meadow to heathland. Egg weight may increase in response to this in both species. C. brunneus also has a corresponding increase in adult mortality. Thus, for both species there is an increase in density-independent mortality of the eggs and/or adults.-from Author

dc:title: Winter activity of pipistrelle bats.
dc:creator: Avery M.I.
dc:description: Pipistrellus pipistrellus leave hibernation to feed in all winter months, though activity is most likely on warm and calm nights. Feeding rates are highest on warm calm nights. Behaviour of the bats shows a good qualitative fit to a simple energetic model of winter activity, but the response of the bats to temperature does not form the predicted step-function. Males seem more often active in winter than females, and more males are active on warmer nights than on cold ones.-from Author

dc:title: The role of profitability in snail kite foraging.
dc:creator: Bourne G.
dc:description: The foraging strategies of 1 pair of breeding and 45 nonbreeding Rostrhamus sociabilis were studied in relation to predictions of Royama's (1970) model of niche hunting by profitability in Guyana, South America. The study did not corroborate or refute the prediction that profitability is the major foraging mechanism. Although the birds tended to spend most foraging time in the most profitable habitat, they had difficulty discriminating among slight differences in habitat profitability. All kites apparently sampled habitats to monitor profitability trends which changed over time, with peaks at 06.00-08.00 and 18.00-20.00, and a low at 12.00- 14.00. No spatial choices were detected relative to habitat-profitability changes, but kites did concentrate hunting efforts in the habitat with the highest prey density. Diet differences between adults and juveniles were associated with differences in handling times. Adults took significantly larger apple snails Pomacea doliodes than did juveniles and spent significantly less time handling these snails. The breeding pair took significantly larger snails back to the nest than they consumed. This behaviour may be better explained by the size-distance relations of central place models than by Royama's handling time to prey size relationships.-from Author

dc:title: Sit-and-wait predators and cryptic prey: a field study with wild birds.
dc:creator: Lawrence E.
dc:description: The ability of 10 colour ringed robins Erithacus rubecula and 9 great tits Parus major to detect immobile, cryptic prey in the wild was recorded. Artificial prey were presented at high density on horizontal backgrounds at ground level (experiment 1). Another type of artificial prey was presented at low density above ground on bark (experiment 2). They prey were either 'cryptic' or 'conspicuous'. In experiment 1, 5 robins simply fed faster on the conspicuous food-there was no evidence that the robins acquired 'search images' during repeated feeding bouts on cryptic prey. Only 2 great tits and a robin out of the 17 birds that started experiment 2 learnt how to detect cryptic prey. The ability to detect cryptic prey from vantage points without relying on movement as a cue, was restricted to only a few birds (of those filmed). Without extensive experience these birds could not learn to deal efficiently with cryptic prey.-from Author

dc:title: Territory size, prey renewal and feeding rates: interpretation of observations on the pied wagtail ( Motacilla alba) by simulation.
dc:creator: Houston A.I.
dc:description: Pied wagtails defend winter feeding territories along a river by walking a regular circuit round their territories, exploiting a renewing food supply (insects washed onto the river banks). A simulation model was used to investigate the effect of territory size on the owner's feeding rate. Larger territories can yield more food because the longer the foraging circuit the greater the time for resource renewal between successive visits to the same stretch. But larger territories cost more to defend. The territory size that maximizes feeding rate or energetic gain varies with the rate of food renewal, smaller territories being better when renewal is fast and larger ones when it is slow. Real wagtails did not track these short-term optima by changing territory size, but maintained a territory size of c600 m throughout the winter. This territory size may promote an owner's long-term chances of over-winter survival. If territory size is <600 m, then many days would yield a feeding rate inadequate for survival, while defending a territory >600 m would not increase the number of profitable feeding days. Simulation was used to explore how changes in intruder pressure, walking speed and ability to detect intruders affect feeding rate; owners would achieve only a slight gain in feeding rate by improving their detection ability beyond the observed values.-from Authors

dc:title: Identifying areas of concentrated use within the home range.
dc:creator: Samuel M.
dc:description: Areas receiving concentrated use by resident animals within their home range can be termed core areas, definable by comparison of the observed space-use pattern with that expected from a uniform pattern of use. A hypothetical data set is applied to radio-telemetry locations of a black bear Ursus americanus. The bear used 2 distinct core areas, which enclosed 34% of the total home range and included 76% of the animal locations. Patterns of core area use are demonstrated for male western tanagers Piranga ludoviciana. Although 90% home range boundaries overlap, core areas for 4 adjacent males closely resemble exclusive-use territories. Interspecific use of core areas of western tanagers and chipping sparrows Spizella passerina are compared. Core areas for chipping sparrows tended to be a larger proportion of the home range and intensity of core area use was greater for western tangers.-from Authors

dc:title: The population dynamics of red and western grey kangaroos in arid New South Wales, Australia. I. Population trends and rainfall.
dc:creator: Bayliss P.
dc:description: Red kangaroo Macropus rufus and western grey kangaroo M. fuliginosa populations were monitored on Kinchega National Park and some adjoining sheep stations. 1973-1976 experienced exceptionally high rainfall providing kangaroos with a superabundance of food. The preceding years were marked by the late 1960's drought and low kangaroo densities, and the following years by average rainfall and high kangaroo densities. The kangaroo populations exhibited two general trends in relation to the exceptional and average rainfall years: a rapid rise and an asymptote. There was no significant difference between the population dynamics of the kangaroos inside the Park and on the adjoining sheep stations, regardless of densitites being 2.5 times higher on the Park. Competition for food by sheep Ovis aries probably suppressed kangaroo densities outside the Park. The exponential rate of increase of all populations was positively correlated with lagged rainfall.-from Author

dc:title: Investment in growth by pregnant wild rabbits in relation to litter size and sex of the offspring.
dc:creator: Boyd I.
dc:description: Oryctolagus cuniculus growth during gestation fitted a linear model. Mean weight increase was 8.2 g day-1(SD 0.378). Growth of females during gestation was not directly related to litter size. Growth of large litters occurred at the expense of non-foetal growth of the mother. There was no reduction in the birth weight of neonates with increased litter size. Birth weight differed significantly between males and females although there was no difference in fat content. Sex ratio at birth was not significantly different from 1:1. The effect on these results of density changes and competition for food was minimized.-from Author

dc:title: The population dynamics of red and western grey kangaroos in arid New South Wales, Australia. II. The numerical response function.
dc:creator: Bayliss P.
dc:description: Two numerical response models were fitted to the rate of increase and lagged rainfall data for red kangaroo Macropus rufus and western grey kangaroos M. fuliginosus inside the Kinchega National Park: the Michaelis-Menton and the Ramp. Both models produced similar estimates of maximum rate of increase (rm) for each species. For red kangaroos there were 0.53 pa (Michaelis-Menton) and 0.58 pa (Ramp); and that for western grey kangaroos, 0.60 pa (Michaelis-Menton) and 0.52 pa (Ramp). Both models produced markedly different estimates of maximum rate of decrease (a) for each species. For red kangaroos these were -1.50 pa (Michaelis-Menton) and 0.30 pa (Ramp); and that for western grey kangaroos, -1.50 pa (Michaelis-Menton) and -0.48 pa (Ramp). The level of rainfall where r equals zero in both models coincides with the annual average rainfall isohyets that mark the western distribution and abundance patterns found for both species in eastern Australia. The rm of a population may be influenced by its current age distribution and sex ratio.-from Author

dc:title: Problems in estimating age-specific survival rates from recovery data of birds ringed as young.
dc:creator: Anderson D.
dc:description: The life table model is frequently used in analysis of ringed samples of young in bird populations. The basic model is biologically unrealistic, of little use in making inferences concerning age-specific survival probabilities, and is thus essentially invalid. Inferences about age-specific survival rates are possible only if both young and adult (or young, subadult and adult) age classes are ringed each year for k years (k = or >2).-from Authors

dc:title: Fur seal diving behaviour in relation to vertical distribution of krill.
dc:creator: Croxall J.P.
dc:description: Continuous records of diving depths of female Antarctic fur seal Arctocephalus gazella on 3-8 day feeding trips to sea from South Georgia were analyzed in conjunction with data on diel changes in the abundance and distribution of their main prey, krill. In 36 complete days foraging by 7 seals, 75% of 4273 dives were at night. Dives then were consistently shallower (dive depth <30 m) than in daytime (mostly 40-75 m). This closely matched changes in the vertical distribution of krill, nearly all of which was below a depth of 50 m from 09.00-15.00 h, with substantial quantities >40 m only between 21.00-06.00 h. Although over 40% of the krill in water column at any time of day was <75 m, only 3% of dives exceeded this depth. Because krill migrate vertically fur seals are able to exploit them most efficiently during shallow dives at night.-from Authors

dc:title: A general relationship between adult weight and the reproductive potential of aphids.
dc:creator: Llewellyn M.
dc:description: Using data from >90 aphid species living on 120 different host-plants, a negative exponential relationship between adult weight and embryo number is described which transcends the influence of both aphid species and host-plant. There is no evidence seasonal trend in this relationship but the rate at which the number of pigmented-eyed embryos increases as alate weight increases rises noticeably from June onwards. Adult alate aphids contain more well-developed embryos as a proportion of total embryos, than do apterous aphids and have a short-term reproductive advantage. This is not the case if total embryo content is used as an index. As adult size increases the number of embryos plateau. Consequently, the number of embryos per unit adult body weight declines as adult size increases. Apterous aphids always have more embryos per unit weight than alate aphids of the same size. Over the whole season adult alatae have a mean weight of 0.79 mg with 32 embryos of which 7 are pigmented. Apterae weigh 1.49 mg with 55 embryos of which 10 are pigmented.-from Authors

dc:title: Seasonality of Psocoptera in two tropical forests in Panama.
dc:creator: Wolda H.
dc:description: In Barro Colorado Island (BCI), with a pronounced 4 months long dry season, psocid species varied in their seasonal fluctuations in abundance, but were, on average, roughly as seasonal as other insects studied there. In Fortuna, a relatively non-seasonal site, psocids were markedly less seasonal, though in some species a clear seasonal pattern was still seen. Most within-year variation in abundance at this site appears to be non-seasonal in that the fluctuation pattern in one year is not repeated in the next. In BCI Psocoptera as a whole show a much less pronounced seasonal variation in abundance than the individual species, because different species have their maxima at different times of the year. Seasonal variations in abundance are perhaps more pronounced in the canopy than at a low level in the forest. At the species level, this suggestion is not confirmed. In terms of changes in abundance from year to year, tropical Psocoptera are just as stable, or variable, as temperate ones.-from Authors

dc:title: The definition and interpretation of guild structure in ecological communities.
dc:creator: Adams J.
dc:description: Psychophysical unfolding theory is employed to define a testable model of guild structure using data derived from a community matrix. The model presents structure visually and may be more biologically realistic than other related models. The technique was applied in detail to data for 4 groups of predatory invertebrates (freshwater triclads, woodland opilionids, field layer spiders and coral reef gastropods) and produced statistically significant results. The dimensions created, linking predators and resources, are interpreted in terms of the original data. As well as determining the existince of guilds the visual models facilitate unique comparisons between communities which appear to have similar structures despite their diverse origins. Unfolding analysis was applied to a further range of groups reported or expected to form guilds. A high rate of positive results suggests that a consensus exists about guild constitution.-from Author

dc:title: Annual variation in reproduction in snakes in a fluctuating environment.
dc:creator: Seigel R.
dc:description: For the North American snakes Diadophis punctatus, Thamnophis radix, T. sirtalis and Agkistrodon contortrix, even after changes in female body size were corrected for, clutch or litter size varied significantly among years in 4 of 5 populations. In 3 populations, clutch size was higher in years having above-normal rainfall. Clutch size in Diadophis was significantly correlated with autumn rainfall. Use of short-term data to compare reproductive traits among geographically separated populations may be misleading. -from Authors

dc:title: The impact of hairy wood ants, Formica lugubris, on the guild structure of herbivorous insects on birch, Betula pubescens.
dc:creator: Fowler S.
dc:description: In the presence of ants the abundance of free-living chewing insects was reduced more than that of leaf tie-ers, which in turn was reduced more than that of fully internal feeders such as leaf-miners. Total species richness of the herbivorous insect community on birch was reduced by ants. Leaf-miners were commoner at ant sites. Ants presumably remove competitors or predators of miners, thereby reducing miner mortality. The ant-tended aphid Symydobius oblongus had population densities >3000% higher in the presence of ants. Birch trees may not benefit from the reduction in species richness of attacking herbivores by ants because the populations of S. oblongus are increased so enormously.-from Authors

dc:title: Phenotypic correlates and ecological consequences of dominance in song sparrows.
dc:creator: Arcese P.
dc:description: Dominance of Melospiza melodia at feeders in their 1st summer was a good predictor of survival to the next spring, and of settlement on a territory. Of several phenotypic characters investigated, only sex and age had strong effects on dominance. Twice as many males were dominant as were females, and date of hatch accounted for over 59% of the total variation in dominance among individuals. Early-hatched birds held in captivity for 34-46 days during their 1st summer achieved the dominance status expected from their age. Site familiarity was therefore not a prerequisite to dominant status. The accumulated experience of an individual in agonistic encounters is probably a key determinant of dominance.-from Authors

dc:title: Age-related differences in the use of time and space by radio- tagged grey herons ( Ardea cinerea) in winter.
dc:creator: Draulans D.
dc:description: First-year grey herons, compared with adults, were radio-tracked proportionally more on a fish-farm, and on roosts around the farm and proportionally less on fish-ponds. Mean length of a stay on foraging grounds was shorter for this age-group which, however, compensated through more daily visits to feeding sites. First-year grey herons, more than adults, improve their foraging efficiency by visiting a fish-farm. First-year grey herons showed more variation in spatial distribution in the course of a season, between seasons and according to weather conditions than adults did. Variations in the use of time, however, were much larger for adult birds. In the course of the day, the proportion of locations on foraging grounds did not vary much for first-year grey herons, in contrast with what was found for the adults. The latter seemed to select the most profitable periods of the day to forage, as far as fishing success is concerned. Young birds appear to be less flexible with regard to their use of time, but adopt more easily a change in spatial distribution. They seem to forage more on less typical areas and in less suitable periods of the day, due to either a lack in skill in hunting and in selecting the best time and place to forage, or due to exclusion from better periods and place to forage by adults. -from Authors

dc:title: Site consistency in kingbird breeding performance: implications for site fidelity.
dc:creator: Blancher P.
dc:description: Four measures of breeding performance were examined in Tyrannus tyrannus rate of nest loss to predation, laying date of first clutches, clutch size, and nestling growth rate. The proportion of times that territories were occupied over 8 yr was compared to these measures of performance. The percentage of variation in breeding performance attributable to consistent differences between parts of the study area across years was 20% for predation rate, 43% for laying date, 14% for clutch size, and 15% for nestling growth. These figures were statistically significant for predation, laying date and clutch size. Territory occupancy by kingbirds was negatively related with both rate of predation and with lateness of egg- laying between parts of the study area. Measures of breeding performance show consistency at sites between years, and thus any tendency of birds to nest preferentially at previously successful sites should be selectively advantageous. Such a tendency appears to be present in kingbirds. -from Authors

dc:title: Population regulation in male and female red deer.
dc:creator: Clutton-Brock T.
dc:description: Analyses and compares the effects of increasing population density on reproduction, survival and emigration in each sex in an increasing population of Cervus elaphus on the Isle of Rhum, Scotland, 1971-83. For both sexes, the key factor was winter mortality which fell principally on calves. Calf winter mortality was density dependent. Increasing density had a stronger effect on survival of males than females, especially during the 2nd year of life. Emigration did not play an important part in regulating density in either sex. The reduced viability of males when food was short may have been caused by their greater nutritional requirements and is probably a consequence of sexual selection.-from Authors

dc:title: Variability in feeding rate and meal size of Leach's storm- petrel at Kent Island, New Brunswick.
dc:creator: Ricklefs R.
dc:description: Meal size, estimated by analysing mass increments of Oceanodroma leucorhoa chicks, over short periods during the night, averaged 10.0 g (SD 2.3 g, range c5-13 g). Mass increments over 24 h (NET) were linearly related to the sum of positive mass increments over 3-h intervals during the night (SUM) by the equation NET = -6.04 + 0.92 SUM. With knowledge of meal size and of this relationship, we estimated the number of feeds per night (0, 1, or 2) from NET. During August in both 1962 and 1983, each parent fed its chick on 43% of nights. Each parent fed independently of the other. Percentages of nights with 0, 1, and 2 feeds were 35, 44, and 21%, which do not differ significantly from the binomial probability function. Intervals between feeds rarely are so long as the period over which chicks could survive utilizing only their substantial fat reserves. This calls into question the prevalent idea that the purpose of the fat deposits is to guarantee survival through periodic fasts resulting from unpredictable food supplies or feeding conditions. Food provisioning in storm-petrels appears to be regulated by the requirements of the chicks, rather than by variation in food resources available to adults. -from Authors

dc:title: Breeding strategies of the blue tit and coal tit ( Parus) in mainland and island Mediterranean habitats: a comparison.
dc:creator: Blondel J.
dc:description: The breeding ecology of blue tits Parus caeruleus and coal tits Parus ater shows very different patterns in Provence and in Corsica. For both species the onset of the breeding season is delayed by c3 wk on the island and the clutch size is reduced by c30%. Corsican tits never have 2nd broods, but 26% of blue tits and 60% of coal tits do have 2nd broods on the mainland. Breeding success is 6.4 young raised per pair for the blue tit and 9.5 for the coal tit on the mainland, compared with 2.6 and 3.0 respectively in Corsica. The proportion of breeding adults 1 yr old is only slightly higher on the island. Insular characteristics of the food supply and its variability on a year round basis are important factors responsible for these differences in population ecology. Comparisons of the growth rates of nestlings and of feeding frequencies between the mainland population and the Corsican population do not support the hypothesis that low reproductive rates on the island could be attributed to intraspecific competition. Nor do results support the view that breeding ecology is determined through mechanisms of optimization of reproductive effort in a trade-off between clutch size and associated life history parameters. Rather they fit Ashmole's hypothesis on the significance of clutch size. A low amount and only a small surplus of food supply during the breeding season are sufficient to explain why the breeding ecology of Corsican tits is so different from that of continental ones.-from Author

dc:title: Individual variation in seasonal breeding success of pied flycatchers ( Ficedula hypoleuca).
dc:creator: Harvey P.
dc:description: Measures of high reproductive success are earlier laying date, larger clutch size and more young fledged. Breeding performances of both sexes improve with age after breeding experience has been controlled for, and with breeding experience after age has been controlled for. Females that have bred as both 1 and 2 year olds are more likely to survive to breed again than those that bred in their 2nd year but failed to breed in their 1st year. A male is more likely to survive to breed again after a breeding season in which its mate laid in early clutch. At least 40% of males and females did not breed in their 1st year in the Forest of Dean, Gloucestershire. -from Authors

dc:title: The spring decline in populations of the bank vole, Clethrionomys glareolus, and the role of female density.
dc:creator: Gipps J.
dc:description: Artificial reduction in female population density by c50% at the beginning of February on experimental areas resulted in a lower rate of decline in the numbers of both sexes than on control areas. Both males and females survived better on the experimental areas than on the control areas. The role of female spacing behaviour in the regulation of vole populations is discussed.-from Authors

dc:title: Population regulation for different life-stages of migratory trout Salmo trutta in a Lake District stream, 1966-83.
dc:creator: Elliott J.
dc:description: From 1966-83, most surviving trout spent 2 yr in fresh water, then migrated to the sea/estuary, and finally returned to spawn in fresh water as either males in their 3rd year or males and females in their 4th year. The sex ratio was c1 for fish of similar age. Survivor density at 5 stages in the life cycle was related to egg density at the start of each year-class. Losses during successive life-stages were effectively zero for the egg-alevin stage (loss-rate ko), density dependent in the 1st spring (k1) and summer (k2) of the life cycle, and density independent within the 1st winter (k3), 2nd summer (k4) and 2nd winter plus post-migration period (k5). Density-dependent survival of young trout (k1,k2) was chiefly responsible for the stock-recruitment relationships for different life-stages; proportionate survival occurred between life-stages of older trout (k3, k4, k5). The 'key factor' for population regulation was spring losses (k1) soon after the young trout started to feed. A predictive equation for total loss-rate was K = k0 + k1 + k2 + k3 + k4 + k5 = 4.399 + 0.665k1. Neither water temperature nor rainfall significantly affected loss-rates except those for 1+ parr (k4) in summer droughts. The relationship between total egg production by the surviving progeny and egg density at the start of a year-class was density dependent; the equilibrium point was c80 eggs m-2. The population rarely exists in dynamic equilibrium because of environmental perturbations such as droughts. -from Author

dc:title: Changes in the biology of the kittiwake Rissa tridactyla: a 31- year study of a breeding colony.
dc:creator: Coulson J.
dc:description: Colony size increased from 4 birds in 1949 until 1965, declined through to 1977, increased again until 1981 but declined in 1982. At its peak, the colony contained 105 breeding pairs. Breeding birds returned to the NE England colony slightly later from 1955 until 1963. This was followed by progressively earlier return until 1978 but more recently, return has become later again. Laying date changed little until 1976, then became progressively later each year. Clutch size increased until 1960, then declined by c10% to 1982. Egg volume and the growth rate of chicks have remained constant. Hatching success of eggs, fledging success of chicks and the number of chicks fledged per pair all initially increased then progressively declined (by 15%, 14% and over 27% respectively). All have recently recovered slightly. The survival rates of breeding females declined during 1966-69 and remained at the new level. The survival rates of males declined for a longer period before recovering slightly. Male and female survival rates deviated markedly from each other in 1954-66 and 1970-78. During the latter period a number of incidences of bigamy and female-female pairs were recorded suggesting that there was a shortage of males recruiting to the colony. In years of higher than average mortality, the 'divorce' rates amongst the surviving pairs were also higher. The early, small changes were probably associated with the changing age structure within the new colony, whereas recent declines probably result from changes in food availability.-from Authors

dc:title: Foraging by the smooth newt ( Triturus vulgaris) on zooplankton: functional responses and diet choice.
dc:creator: Ranta E.
dc:description: Functional responses of the predator to prey density were type II (Holling) for 2 sizes of Daphnia. Tadpoles ate greater numbers of D. longispina than D. magna. Adults in contrast ate more D. magna, but the difference was small. Feeding on D. magna was more profitable than feeding on D. longispina; 2-3 times for tadpoles and 10 times for adults in terms of energy per handling time. Foraging by newts will probably alter the size distribution of zooplankton in natural environments.-from Authors

dc:title: Population dynamics of the social wasps Vespula vulgaris and Vespula germanica in England.
dc:creator: Archer M.
dc:description: Colonies of Vespula vulgaris and V. germanica (Hymenoptera: Vespidae) show the following characteristics: 1) large variations in yearly abundance with, in the main, 2) a 2- and possibly a 7-yr cycle; 3) exceptional years of abundance and scarcity tend to occur in pairs; 4) spring queens are scarce during exceptional years of summer abundance and numerous in exceptional years of summer scarcity. These characteristics are apparently generated by an over-compensating endogenous mechanism which damps colony counts to equilibrium. The equilibrium may be perturbed by an exogenous factor. The endogenous mechanism is probably driven by either density-related intra-specific usurpation of early nests by spring queens or density-related variation in queen quality, or both. The exogenous factor is probably a function of summer and autumn weather.-from Author

dc:title: Ades: new ecological families of species-specific frequency distributions that describe repeated spatial samples with an intrinsic power-law variance-mean property.
dc:creator: Perry J.
dc:description: The Ades are families of new 3-parameter distributions with 2 parameters (tau and r) common to all distributions within a family, and one (iota ) unique to each. When fitted to sets of data, the total number of parameters is only 2 more than the number of sets. Families of Ades distributions performed as well as, or better than, negative binomials when fitted to 7 classical species' data sets. Frequency distributions within the Ades family conformed accurately to the variance-mean power-law relationship. Where 2 species' regressions intersect, and 2 species' frequency distributions may be quite different for the same variance and mean. Fitted values of the negative binomial k differed widely between samples within each data set and varied with density according to functional forms predicted previously.-from Authors

dc:title: The diversity of Psocoptera in two tropical forests in Panama.
dc:creator: Broadhead E.
dc:description: Light traps operating in the canopy and near the ground in the lowland monsoon forest of Barro Colorado Island (BCI) yielded 148 species of Psocoptera. A light trap operating in a humid non-seasonal montane forest at Fortuna, Chiriqui Province, yielded 84 species. The species frequency distributions at both places can adequately be described by the log-series model. Diversity at BCI is much greater than that at Fortuna. Only 7 out of the total of 225 species occur at both places. Many species in the traps are represented by a preponderance of males but sex ratios vary from 9-100%. At BCI, diversity in the canopy is slightly lower than near the ground, especially so in the wet season. Densities of individuals are greater in the canopy than near the ground in the wet season but lower in the canopy than near the ground in the dry season. Density varies greatly with season in the canopy but only slightly so near the ground. There are few exclusively upperstorey or understorey species. There is a preponderance of species with a wide vertical representation in the forest. The 2 forests differ greatly in the relative abundance of bark- and leaf-frequenters, but in both forests there is a higher proportion of leaf-frequenters in the canopy than near the ground. Gut content analyses of the 30 commonest species at BCI show that the majority of species are alga-fungal spore feeders.-from Authors

dc:title: Interspecific competition and niche shifts in tits and the goldcrest: an experiment.
dc:creator: Alatalo R.
dc:description: In coniferous forests in Central Sweden willow tit Parus montanus and crested tit P. cristatus forage in the inner canopy while coal tit P. ater and goldcrest Regulus regulus forage on the outer, needled tree parts. Interspecific competition is shown to affect foraging site selection of sympatric tits and goldcrests.-from Authors

dc:title: Spring arrival times and assortative mating of kestrels in south Scotland.
dc:creator: Village A.
dc:description: In a partially migrant population of Falco tinnunculus in S Scotland, migrants settled in spring from late February until late April. Mean arrival time was earlier following a mild winter, but was not related to local food supply, so that the mean length of courtship (pairing to egg-laying) was longer in a poor vole year (when laying was late) than in good times (when laying was early). Within years, migrants that arrived early tended to pair earlier, and lay earlier, than those that arrived late. Later pairing birds partly compensated for this by having shorter courtship than those that paired early. Males and females arrived over roughly the same period and there was no difference in mean arrival dates, but within pairs, the males arrived c4 days on average before their females. The sex ratio of winter residents was biased towards males, so more early arriving females than males were able to pair with residents on arrival. This resulted in a surplus of unpaired males that persisted until the end of the settling period when all breeding birds were paired. In the 2 years when they bred in substantial numbers, first-year birds arrived later than adults. In males, but not females, first-year birds resident over winter waited longer than adults before finding a mate. Selective mating of first-year birds and adults occurred in 1978 but not 1979.-from Author

dc:title: Population and energy dynamics of trout Salmo trutta in a small Danish stream.
dc:creator: Mortensen E.
dc:description: From March 1974-April 1976, annual production in th 2yr was 88.9 (95% CL 82.6-97.4) and 65.8kJ m-2 (60.8-73.1), respectively, and the maximum rate of production coincided with the period of maximum growth rates.-from Author

dc:title: Life-cycle and production of the burrowing mayfly, Ephemera danica: a new method for estimating degree-days required for growth.
dc:creator: Tokeshi M.
dc:description: A maximum likelihood method was used to estimate the number of degree-days required to complete E. danica nymphal growth in the River Tud, Norfolk. Minimum threshold temperatures for growth were 2.6oC for males and 3.1oC for remales. From the estimates of degree-days required to reach maturity and the temperature regime of the study site, it was concluded that some larger males should emerge as adults in 1yr, whereas the rest, and all females, should take 2yr to mature. This agrees with the pattern observed in size-frequency distribution of E. danica nymphs throughout the year. Annual population production of the 2yr classes combined was 5.58g dry weight m-2yr-1, with the older year-class contributing approx 85% of the total. Females accounted for 60-70% of production. Monthly production in summer was as much as 10- times that in winter. Production biomass ratios showed relatively low values (<2.1), a pattern that may be general in semi-voltine species.-from Author

dc:title: Growth, size, biomass and production for different life-stages of migratory trout Salmo trutta in a Lake District stream, 1966-83.
dc:creator: Elliott J.
dc:description: Mean sizes and mean specific growth rates for different life stages varied considerably between year-classes, and were not density dependent. Water temperature and, to a lesser extent, alevin weight were the chief factors affecting growth in fresh water; food was not a limiting factor, except for approx 6 months in the 1st autumn-spring period of the life cycle and for 1st-year trout in 2 summer drought (1976, 1983). Mean sizes of adults returning to spawn in fresh water were directly related to mean sizes of juveniles at the start of their migration to the sea/estuary. The relative variation in individual fish size (measured by CV) in each year-class was inversely related to initial density of eggs or alevins and thus density dependent. Variations in biomass were chiefly due to variations in growth rather than numbers. Most of the variation in total freshwater production in the different year-classes (range 17.43-33.88g m-2) was due to the combined effect of density-dependent survival (38%) and density-independent growth (30%). Annual production over 16yr (range 12.17-33.90g m-2, mean 24.39g m-2) was higher than that recorded for most, but not all, trout streams.-from Author
